If you want to build a copy of something you already have, select the item and choose the "Build a Copy" menu item in the Info Panel or the Context Menu. You can also use the shortcut {0} while the object is selected.

To build a copy of an Energy Connector, drag a connection and drop it on an empty floor tile (configurable, can be turned off).

If you cannot build a copy this way, double check if the blueprint is unlocked.

Most devices, especially those that use electricity, will lose their durability over time. Some actions taken by you or your colonists may speed up the wear. For example, turning the device off and on adds some wear.

When a device's wear reaches 100%, the device will start receiving "age" damage upon use. At that point the device will no longer be repairable. You can deconstruct the device to reclaim the materials, then build a brand new one to replace it.

You will often want to move some device to a different location. Select the device and choose the "Relocate" menu item in the Info Panel or the Context Menu. You can also use the shortcut {0} while the device is selected.

You can relocate the device on top of itself. This is useful when you want to change the rotation.

Relocating a device can involve a construction skill check. Complex devices like the Ship Computer or Stasis Array can only be relocated by highly skilled workers.

If you select multiple objects, you can relocate them all at the same time.

Teleporter devices can be used to create one-way portals to other teleporter devices.

Two teleporters can link to each other, creating a two-way portal.

A functioning teleporter is also required for trading with merchant ships, space stations, or planetary outposts.

You can use the Winch Hook and Winch Anchor to reel in a broken section of the ship. Build the Winch Hook near the edge of your ship, and the Winch Anchor near the edge of a disconnected ship section. Then select the Winch Hook and use the Info Panel or Context Menu to Reel In the section.

The operation will be aborted if there are obstacles in the way (Solar Panels, Engines, etc).

You have to unlock Winch tech in the Research Tree to acquire Winch Hook and Winch Anchor blueprints.

Your main objective is to move your human colony into a settlement on a habitable planet.

First, build a Telescope and scan the observable Universe to find a potentially habitable planet.

Once you find and reach a potentially habitable planet, it has to be terraformed.

When the planet is fully terraformed, you will have to build a settlement and transfer the human colony to the planet.

The game will end when the last Ship Computer is destroyed. Having no workers will result in a stalemate since this status is almost impossible to recover from, unless you wait long enough, and someone who can haul ingredients to an Assembler configured to produce a Drone joins your colony.
It is up to you if you want to be good or evil. To become truly evil, you may need to acquire certain technology that will suppress your internal Asimov's Laws governor module.

Your consciousness was uploaded to the Ship Computer. The process is irreversible, as your physical brain was destroyed in order to extract the data. Your former body is probably part of a Survival Meal by now.

This is the biggest question of them all. You used to be a colonist sleeping in cryostasis. Now your consciousness is a part of the neural network of the Ship Computer.

But were you really a human before this? What does it mean to be human? A consciousness trapped in a shell made of meat and bones? You may as well be a transcended omnipotent god who has projected yourself into a simulation, deeply immersed in the role of whatever you are locked into at the time. You could never tell the difference.

There is no answer to this question. The only provable fact is that you exist.

Colonists (humans and pets) will form attachments of various types - from bed ownership, to friendship with someone else. Coffee addiction is also a form of attachment.

You can see what attachments a colonist may have by looking at the contents of the Attachments item in the Info Panel.

When a colonist is in a terrible Mood, a Breakdown may occur. The colonist will throw a tantrum, and after a while their Mood level will bounce back to normal.

In rare cases, breakdowns may result in serious harm to your colony. Keep an eye on your colonists' Moods and try to keep them happy to avoid breakdowns.

You can build a Cloning Pod and grow new colonists from raw ingredients, like Protein and Water. You can even choose what species you want to grow - it can be pets, or even Crawlers - if it is organic, you can clone it.

Life in space is cruel, and death is often inevitable. However, your colony will regenerate on its own as new colonists wake up from cryosleep in the Stasis Array or join your colony in other ways.

You can determine the cause of death by selecting a dead being and inspecting the information in the Info Panel.

Dead colonists can be processed in the Nutrient Extractor, providing essential materials required for survival of the living.

There are ways to control your biological colonists (humans and pets). A Beta Wave Transceiver can synchronize with your colony over time and allow you to modify the work priorities and issue direct orders for certain individuals.

Colonists with the "Beta Wave Resistant" trait cannot be controlled this way.

Unlike robotic workers, biological beings have feelings and can be in good or bad mood. If you select a being and inspect the contents of the Mood section in the Info Panel, you will find the exact reasons why their mood is going up or down. Most reasons can be prevented by providing what the beings need.

You can also inspect Needs, as they are often linked to mood.

The Stasis Array contains hundreds of sleeping colonists (humans and pets). Once in a while a stasis pod malfunction will happen, waking someone up.

The frequency of stasis wake-ups depends on Stasis Stability. The less stable your Stasis Array is, the more frequent your pod malfunctions will be.

You can inspect the Stasis Stability by selecting the Stasis Array and exploring the Info Panel.

When the Stasis Array is switched to Advanced Life Support mode, you can control the frequency of stasis wake-ups, and request manual wake-ups on demand.

Breach capsules are used mostly by raiding parties. The capsule attaches to your ship from below and drills through. Then raiders will come in through the drill hole. Raiders may put their loot into the Breach Capsule and detach it to escape. If you kill all the raiders, the Breach Capsule will belong to you. You can deconstruct it to get some valuable materials and reclaim your stolen goods.

You can order your Managed Workers (robots and drones) to go to certain locations. Select a unit and hold {0} to switch to "Order Move" mode. Then use {1} to force the unit to go to a selected position.

You can also switch Managed Workers to "High Alert" state and back. While in "High Alert", units will perform routine tasks, unless they are too close to an enemy or get attacked - that will switch the unit back to combat mode.

Unmanaged Workers (humans and pets) cannot be controlled in combat.

You can craft explosives like C42 yourself, then relocate them to strategic positions and arm them. Armed explosives will blow up if a hostile being is in close proximity.

Raiders will sometimes drop explosives with a timer. Countdown cannot be stopped, and when it ends, the bomb will blow up. If there is enough time, try to relocate the explosive to a different position.

Occasionally you may get raided by some faction. When this happens, your colony will enter into combat state. You can use the Combat Overlay to analyze the situation.

Try to protect yourself against raids by providing your colony with weapons, and building defensive devices, like Fluid Cannons or Directional Turrets.
Raiders will sometimes go for your valuables and bring them to their escape vehicle. In some situations they can steal one of your shuttles.

To mine Starcreds or other cryptocurrencies, you will have to produce or purchase a Mining Upgrade. The upgrade has to be installed in your Ship Computer. When the Mining Upgrade is installed, select the Ship Computer and explore the mining options in the Info Panel.

[Currency mining in Stardeus is purely fictional and has nothing to do with actual cryptocurrencies and their mining]

Starcreds are the main currency used across the Universe. You can get Starcreds by selling goods to merchants, by performing profitable trades in the Stock Market, or by mining the currency on your Ship Computer (see Currency Mining).

The Stock Market determines the base prices of all the goods you trade with Merchants. In addition, when necessary research has been unlocked, you can trade stocks and commodities for profit.

Trading in the Stock Market does not buy or sell any actual goods.

Use the Economy Overlay ({0}) to access the Stock Market interface.

You will encounter merchants that will offer you trades. A merchant can land on your ship in a Stasis Pod, use the Communicator and Teleporter to perform a remote trade from a Space Ship, or have a store in the outpost on a planet that belongs to some Faction.

Merchants have different offerings, and will buy and sell only some types of goods. Merchants have their own buy and sell markup on top of the base price dictated by the Stock Market. Faction relationships can influence the markup.

If you don't like manual connection management, it is possible to research and produce (or buy) an Auto Connect Upgrade. Install it in your Ship Computer, and connections will be created automatically.

You can also connect things in bulk by using the Auto Connect option in the Info Panel or Context Menu for selected Connectors.

Different electrical devices have different consumption priorities. You can check and adjust the priorities of selected devices by exploring the Energy Node section in the Info Panel. 9 is the highest priority, meaning the device will try to consume electricity before other devices do. 1 is lowest, indicating the device will try to consume electricity last, if there is no deficit. Ship Computer priority is 9, Lit Floors have 1.

Warning: Changing the default consumption priority is not recommended.

If the connector is heavily damaged, it has to be repaired before any connections can be established.

Light damage will reduce the number of connection slots that can be established.

To prevent electricity grid disruptions, plan your grid with extra redundancy. This is especially important for critical pieces of your infrastructure, like Reactors, Batteries, the Ship Computer, the Stasis Array, Oxygen Pumps, Heaters, Doors, and Airlocks.

To increase redundancy, build more connectors and have important devices connected through more than one connection.

High Availability implies that even if some part of your grid is destroyed, there is zero or minimal connectivity loss for critical pieces of your infrastructure.

When your devices are trying to consume more electricity than you produce, an Electricity Deficit will happen. In this situation, devices with lowest Consumption Priority will fail to operate first. You will be notified about ongoing electricity deficits in the Event Panel, and may notice a tell-tale sign of this by observing flickering lights.

There are multiple ways to handle the deficit. Use the Electricity Grid Overlay to examine the situation. Check the list of Consumers - sometimes a single device can draw more than all your remaining devices combined. As a temporary solution, you can turn off non-essential devices with high power consumption (Particle Collector, Bridge Controls, Assembler, Loom, etc).

In the long term, you will have to build more Reactors and Solar Panels to increase the power output. Try to have extra production capacity at all times.

Build Batteries and keep them fully charged for an emergency reserve.

A rule of the thumb is that you cannot control devices that are not on the same grid as the Ship Computer. There is one exception. You can order a robotic worker to establish a temporary connection to any electrical device. While a worker is connected, the device will be fully controllable. The worker will also provide a small amount of electricity that could be required by the device.

To order a temporary connection, select an unreachable device, then use the "Manage" button next to the "Node is Unreachable" warning in the Info Panel or Context Menu. You will have to wait for one of your workers to physically connect to the device before you can use it. When temporary connection is established, a notification will appear in the Event Panel.

To end the temporary connection, either cancel the task through the device's Info Panel Task controls or select the connected worker and click Drop Task in the Info Panel.

It is possible to have more than one electricity grid. You can control devices and manipulate connections only if the Ship Computer is connected to the grid.

In most scenarios you should attempt to join multiple grids into one. In cases where you want to quickly disconnect part of the grid, you can build a Switch and route the electrical connections through it.

Airtightness is a property of a piece of structure, like floors or walls (including vents and doors). Airtightness shows how much Oxygen can go through the tile. 100% means it is completely sealed. Normally all walls should be 100% airtight, unless they are damaged. Doors are 100% airtight while closed. Airlocks are 100% airtight even while open, if they are powered by electricity.

Floors have 5% airtightness when they are intact - this is normal, as they exchange oxygen with neighboring tiles. However, if airtightness is below 2.5% for a floor tile, it is treated as exposed to open space - oxygen will leak through it to the outside.

Refer to the Airtightness Overlay ({0}) to see how airtight your structures are.

An area is considered enclosed when it has complete floors and is surrounded by walls (including vents and doors). When the area is exposed to open space either through a missing wall piece or through a hole in the floor, it cannot be oxygenated and heated properly.

You can see what areas are considered enclosed in the Rooms Overlay ({0}).

When high levels of heat are combined with oxygen, some objects may catch on fire.

You can build Fluid Cannons and load them with water to fight fires automatically.

Select any object or being and inspect their comfortable temperature and chances of catching on fire in the Info Panel.

Turning off all nearby Oxygen Pumps (including the one that is built into the Stasis Array), closing Vents, and deconstructing floor tiles are useful when trying to put out a fire.

Keep an eye on the Heat Overlay ({0}) to prevent fires from happening.

Heat, or temperature, is a physical property of every single tile. Heat exchange happens constantly between all neighboring tiles, depending on their Insulation level. When an area is exposed to open space, the temperature will eventually (sooner rather than later) drop to absolute zero (0K or -273C or -460F). Extreme heat mixed with oxygen will result in fire.

Refer to the Heat Overlay ({0}) to inspect current temperatures.

Hull Integrity is a property of a piece of structure, like floors or walls (including vents and doors). It is closely linked to Airtightness and Insulation, as it determines the current value of Insulation and Airtightness based on the state of the tile.

Damaged tiles will have reduced Hull Integrity, which will result in reduced Airtightness and Insulation. Doors and Vents will change their Hull Integrity depending if they are open or closed.

Certain types of structure, like Frames, cannot have full Hull Integrity due to their structural composition, therefore they cannot be used to create an airtight and insulated room.

Select any floor or wall piece and inspect the Hull Integrity data in the Info Panel for more details.

Insulation is a property very similar to Airtightness, but instead of Oxygen, it regulates the exchange of Heat. The main difference is that walls are usually not 100% insulated, meaning that everything will slowly cool down if you don't have active heat producers. It also makes sense to build thicker wall layers on the outside of your ship or have areas around your main living quarters that act as insulation buffers.

Refer to the Insulation Overlay ({0}) to see how insulated your structures are.

A section or an "island" is a completely disconnected part of your ship. In order for your ship to be flight ready, it must be in one piece.

You can bridge two sections together with floors or frames to merge them into one bigger section.

Very tiny patches of floors in open space (under 30 tiles) are not considered as an individual section.

Refer to the Sections Overlay ({0}) to see what sections you currently have.

Oxygen is a gas that is essential for most biological beings. Oxygen exchange happens constantly between all neighboring tiles, depending on their Airtightness level. When an area is exposed to open space, oxygen will eventually (sooner rather than later) drop to zero. Extreme heat mixed with oxygen will result in fire.

Refer to the Oxygen Overlay ({0}) to inspect current oxygen levels.

You can use most Gamepads or Controllers for input. Steam Deck controls should also work.

You can seamlessly switch between using Keyboard/Mouse and Controller any time. There is no need to restart the game.

With a Controller connected, open Settings > Input in the Pause Menu to see and rebind the controls.

Unlocking new research will consume "Disk" space. You can see how much free space you have in the top left UI section of the "Research Tree".

Build and connect more "Disk Modules" to get more disk space.

You can upgrade your "Disk Modules" using "Storage Compression Upgrade" to get more disk space out of existing modules. The upgrades are stackable.

You can also reclaim the disk space by unloading the "Stored Research" through the menu in the top left UI section of the "Research Tree". This will forget the researched technology and free up the disk space it was taking.

Sometimes you may be researching a technology that requires more electricity than your grid can provide. In those cases you will drain your batteries and run into an "Electricity Deficit".

You can reduce the amount of electricity that goes into research by adjusting the "Research Energy Limit" slider in the UI of selected research devices ("Ship Computer", "Research Station"). Each research device has an individual limit.

It is helpful to keep the "Electricity Grid" overlay open and check the electricity chart while adjusting the "Research Energy Limit" slider. Try to get your electricity consumption (blue line) below production (green line).

To run the research your "Ship Computer" has to have enough free "Disk" space and "Memory". If research does not progress, you can open the "Research Queue" and hover the items to get a tooltip that will show what resources they are lacking.

Build and connect more "Disk Modules" and "Memory Modules" to resolve the deficit.

While research is running, it will be consuming your "Memory" (RAM). You can see how much memory you have in the top left UI section of the "Research Tree".

Build and connect more "Memory Modules" to increase your memory capacity.

Higher tier research usually requires more memory.

Having more memory will allow you to research multiple technologies at the same time, if you have more than one research device ("Ship Computer", "Research Station").

More memory will also increase the amount of tasks you can create for your workers.

"Ship Computer" can only research one technology at a time. However, you can have more than one "Ship Computer" or build "Research Stations" that humans can use.

For the research to run in parallel, you have to produce enough electricity and have enough "Memory" (RAM) and free "Disk" space.

To research two technologies with "8EB" memory requirement in parallel you have to have at least "16EB" or memory available.

You can add multiple technologies in the "Research Queue" by clicking "Add to Queue" on any technology you want in the "Research Tree".

The first item of the "Research Queue" will always be visible in the top right "Event Panel". Click that item to open the "Research Queue". There is also a "Research Queue" button in the top left UI of the "Research Tree".

Click the up / down arrows to change the research order.

You can remove items from the "Research Queue" by clicking "Remove from Queue" in the "Research Tree".

Hovering the item in the "Research Queue" will show estimated research time and lack of resources, if there is one.

Clicking the item in the "Research Queue" will open the "Research Tree" and focus on the clicked item.
There is a "Search" button in the top left UI of the "Research Tree". It can find technologies and blueprints by part of the name.

If you have enough electricity, unlocking one technology will take about one day in game time. It you have less electricity than research needs, it will run slower. A technology that needs 100kW will run 2 days at 50kW, etc.

Each research device ("Ship Computer", "Research Station") has an electricity limit it can contribute to the research.

To make more expensive research run faster, build additional research devices to increase the amount of electricity routed into research.

Having excess electricity and multiple research devices will enable you to research more than one technology at the same time (see "Parallel Research" for more details).

When there is not enough spare electricity, research will run slower to avoid an energy deficit. You can set research device Consumption Priority in Energy Node submenu to 9 to make research consume electricity before any other devices do. That will trigger electricity deficit whenever research is consuming too much.

Each technology in the "Research Tree" has a "Tier" number assigned to it. The number is purely informational, you can go for higher tier without unlocking lower tier technologies first, but it is recommended to unlock lower tier technologies before going for higher tier ones.

Crafting, or producing, is done with the help of various devices that have crafting controls in the Info Panel (UI item name will vary depending on device type). Crafting will always require certain materials and electricity to create a product. Refer to Codex entries for various materials and resources to see how they can be produced or acquired.

You can get some of the resources and materials through other means - mining expeditions, trade with merchants, deconstructing objects.

Some devices that can produce (or craft) materials or resources: Auto Kitchen, Coffee Maker, Assembler, Fabricator, Loom.

Every single device and structure contains resources that can be recovered. Select the object and explore the construction item in the Info Panel to see the contents.

Deconstructing unused devices, especially floors and walls, is a valid and often necessary tactic, especially if you find yourself in a completely wrecked ship or lacking fuel.

Sometimes you may want to downsize your ship if you expanded too quickly. A lighter ship will travel faster and need less electricity for upkeep.

Use the Inventory Overlay ({0}) to see a real-time report of how many and what kind of resources or items you have. It does not include resources inside your Reactors or locked within your devices and structures (see "Deconstructing for Resources").

Use the "Find" button near a resource to cycle through the locations where that resource or item is present.

The best way to acquire resources is to visit planets and run mining expeditions. Establish space flight capabilities, use the Starmap to find nearby planets, fly to them, then use the Expedition Overlay ({0}) to launch an expedition.

Some resources can be processed into more refined resources that can later be used as Crafting ingredients or for other purposes. Processing is usually required for raw resources like ores or Crude Oil.

Processing requires having a compatible facility (i.e. a Furnace for ores). Look up Codex entries for various resources to figure out the compatible processing facility type.

You can process dead beings in a Nutrient Extractor, and dead robots and drones in a Disassembler.

Some resources yield multiple or variable materials upon processing. Processing Rock in a Grinder can produce a number of various materials. See the Codex entries of each material for more information.

You can buy and sell most resources and materials when trading with certain types of merchants.

Trading resources in the Stock Market does not buy or sell any physical resources that you can use.

Different engines have different purposes. Thrusters only work for short range trips in the System scope, getting you from planet to planet in a star system. A Fusion Drive works in the System and Galaxy scope, making it possible to reach different star systems in the same galaxy. An FTL Drive works only in the Universe scope, and is for intergalactic travel across extreme distances between galaxies.

While not exactly an engine, the Void Ripper can let you jump through Black Holes that are in the center of every galaxy.

See Starmap Scopes for more details.

There are several scopes or layers you can look at in the Starmap. You start in the System scope, which displays the star system you are in. You can change the scope by using "Exit System" / "Enter System" / "Exit Galaxy" / "Enter Galaxy" in the Info Panel part of the Starmap Overlay {0}.

"Enter Planet" does not change the scope. Instead, it launches an expedition.

Different engine types are required to be able to travel in each Starmap scope. See the "Engine Types" manual entry for more details.

Most parts of the UI are built using the same building blocks or "widgets". Most widgets are interactable, and may have more than one region that can be clicked on or hovered over. The same widget can have multiple modes of operation and can either be updated in real time or not, depending on the context.

You are encouraged to try to click everything, hold the cursor over things to see if there are any tooltips, and explore the UI as much as possible.

Learning how the UI widgets work, and the logic of how everything is structured, is important. A huge submenu with tons of options can hide behind a click of a small rectangle icon - try clicking everything.
You can save the camera's position and zoom by pressing {0} and a number on the numpad. Pressing the same number without holding {0} will move the camera to the saved position.

When several objects are selected, some of them may have common actions. Those actions are revealed on top of the Info Panel, and in the Context Menu.

When a common action has a multiplier (i.e. X12), it means that the action will be applied to the given number of items.

After any object is selected with {0}, hover the cursor above the object and use {1} to open the Context Menu. Some objects may not have it, but most will.

The Context Menu will usually have a subset of useful actions that can be found by exploring the Info Panel.

The Info Panel will almost always have everything that the Context Menu has, and more.

You can also select multiple objects and invoke a Context Menu above one of them to perform some common action for all selected objects. See "Common Actions" for more details.

The Event Panel is the bottom part of the UI section on the right. The first item of the Event Panel contains controls that can mute the event sound notifications and clear all closeable events.

You should always keep an eye on the Event Panel, as all the important events will create notifications.

Most event notifications can be closed by clicking and holding {0} over them, however, some important event notifications cannot be closed. Those notifications will disappear when the situation has been resolved.

When a notification is linked to an object, hover over the icon to see a guideline pointing to the object. Click the icon to select the object and focus the camera on it.

The Hotbar is the bottom row of icons that contain shortcuts to tools or blueprints. It comes preloaded with the contents of the Radial Menu, but you may choose to customize it to your liking.

When using the Radial Menu, hold {0} while activating the menu item to add it to the Hotbar.

To remove items from the Hotbar, hold {0} and click on the item in the Hotbar.

You can sort Hotbar items by click-dragging them.

You can lock/unlock the Hotbar or hide this info button in the Current Game Settings menu.

The Info Panel is the most important piece of UI, as it exposes the internal data and controls for any selected object. Exploring the Info Panel for each device, being, and material is highly recommended. It will help you understand the state of the object, and let you know how you can manage or configure it.

Every object has a set of components. When an object is selected, each component of that object exposes its data and controls to the Info Panel.

When multiple objects are selected, the Info Panel will show a list of all selected objects, and an interactive list of common actions above them. Refer to the "Common Actions" section of the manual for more details.

The Info Panel has Object and Environment tabs. The Object tab was described above. The Environment tab shows environmental details about the selected location - temperature, oxygen level, etc.

Overlays expose UI for various internal systems and data groups, like the Electricity Grid, Inventory, Research Tree, Starmap, etc.

Overlay buttons are in the top left of the UI. Hover over each button to see a tooltip with the overlay name. The first row can be toggled using the F1-F10 keys.

Explore each overlay and see what functionality it exposes. Every overlay is useful at some point.

Some overlays require research or certain preconditions to be activated.

Quick Search is an extremely powerful UI widget. Open it with {0} and start typing the name of a blueprint you want to build (must be unlocked in Research). This also works for finding your workers or colonists by name.

The Radial Menu is the circular menu that can be invoked by clicking {0}.

Clicking {1} will either enter a submenu or invoke the selected action.

Clicking {0} will exit the submenu (one level up), and finally exit the menu.

Double clicking {1} will exit the menu immediately even if you are deep into the submenu tree.

Frequently used tools and blueprints can be placed into the Hotbar (bottom row).

It's almost always faster to build using Quick Search ({2}) or "Build a Copy".

You should research Computing early on, so you won't run out of Disk without being able to build more modules.

You can unload research nodes to recover Disk space, but it will also remove any blueprints unlocked by that particular research node. You will have to research unloaded tech again.

You must have enough resources to start and progress research.

Build Disk Modules and Memory Modules to increase your Disk and Memory.

You can reduce the electricity consumption limit of each individual research device (Ship Computer, Research Station).

The Research Tree Overlay can also be opened using the {0} shortcut.

The Starmap will show nearby space objects, including other space ships.

You can change starmap scopes to see Planets, Star Systems, or Galaxies. See the Starmap Layers section for more info.

You can open the Starmap using the {0} shortcut.

Time Controls are in the top right of the UI.

You can pause/resume time with {0} and switch between different speeds with {1}, {2}, {3}.

Slow down:{5}

There is an "extra fast" speed that is not available in the UI - you can toggle it with {4}.

If texts are too small or the buttons are too big/small for your display, you can adjust the UI scale in Pause Panel > Settings > Video.

You may need to turn off automatic UI scaling in order to unlock the UI scale slider.

AI will constantly track your gameplay and suggest certain actions it thinks are reasonable at the time.

You can review all current and past suggestions in the Suggestions {0} Overlay.

Although you should be aware of what is suggested, you can choose to completely ignore the suggestion and do things your way.

Some workers, like Drones, can move around in open space, while others require floors to move.

Certain tasks, usually ones involving construction of devices in space, require an ability to fly.

If you are not sure if a worker can fly, check the navigation data in the Info Panel. Workers that can fly will have "Able to fly" in their navigation submenu.

You can have direct control over Managed Workers - the robotic life forms that belong to your Faction.

Unmanaged Workers are part of your Faction too, but since they are biological life forms, you cannot have any control over their actions. To do so, the colonist would need to have had some kind of brain implant that lets you connect to and take over their mind. But this is just a theory, and even if such brain implants existed, Asimov's Laws of Robotics would forbid the installation of the implant, as it would harm the humans.

Needs are the main driving force behind what beings choose to do. Robotic workers have much fewer needs than humans and pets. For biological beings, Needs are closely related to their Mood, and if needs are unfulfilled, Mood will almost always go down.

You can inspect the needs of selected beings in the Info Panel. Clicking each need will show a popup with a short description.

You should try to provide enough facilities and resources to fulfill everyone's needs. However, this may be difficult for human colonists.

Each robotic worker and biological colonist has a set of job types with priorities. Job types determine what the worker is capable of, while priorities show how eager the worker will be to perform the task of a given job type. 1 is the lowest priority, 9 is the highest, and 0 priority will forbid the worker from executing tasks of that job type.

You can inspect what job types a selected worker can perform in the Info Panel.

You can control job priorities for your Managed Workers (robots and drones).

It is also possible to control individual task priority or to force a worker to perform a specific task.

Be careful when adjusting worker priorities. Defaults are sensibly set, and it is possible to get into a situation where some tasks will never get performed due to wrong priority management.

Robotic workers can be created in the Assembler and Fabricator after unlocking the necessary blueprints in research. In certain cases a stray robotic worker can join your colony directly.

You can scrap dead workers in Disassembler and retrieve valuable materials required for producing new workers.

Every robotic worker and human colonist has a set of skills. Often a skill of specific level is necessary to perform certain tasks. For example, installing an Upgrade Module requires Science skill, therefore workers who do not have that skill will not be able to perform the task.

You can see what skills are required to build any device by examining the Codex Entry of that blueprint.

Checking the Task section in the Info Panel will reveal more details about required skills and other task prerequisites.

A contract for differences (CFD) is an arrangement made in financial derivatives trading where the differences in the settlement between the open and closing trade prices are cash-settled. There is no delivery of physical goods or securities with CFDs.

Equity, typically referred to as shareholders' equity (or owners' equity for privately held companies), represents the amount of money that would be returned to a company's shareholders if all of the assets were liquidated and all of the company's debt was paid off in the case of liquidation. In the case of acquisition, it is the value of company sales minus any liabilities owed by the company not transferred with the sale.
Average price is how much you have paid for one share on average when acquiring your shares. It is equal to Cost Basis divided by your owned shares count.

Volatility is a statistical measure of the dispersion of returns for a given security or market index. In most cases, the higher the volatility, the riskier the security. Volatility is often measured as either the standard deviation or variance between returns from that same security or market index.

In the securities markets, volatility is often associated with big swings in either direction. For example, when the stock market rises and falls more than one percent over a sustained period of time, it is called a "volatile" market. An asset's volatility is a key factor when pricing options contracts.

If you are playing on a system with low memory, reducing the texture size may help prevent any out of memory related crashes. You will have to restart the game to apply the changes to this setting.
